docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Sacks explored some of the brain’s strangest pathways in best-selling case histories like “The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat,” achieving a level of renown rare among scientists.

headline.main: Oliver Sacks, Neurologist Who Wrote About the Brain’s Quirks, Dies at 82
headline.print_headline: Oliver Sacks, Neurologist Who Wrote About the Brain’s Quirks, Dies at 82

docs.abstract: Oliver Sacks, British neurologist and acclaimed author who explored mysteries of human brain in best-selling case histories, using his patients' struggles as starting points for stirring reflections on consciousness and human condition, dies at age 82.
docs.snippet: Dr. Sacks explored some of the brain’s strangest pathways in best-selling case histories like “The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat,” achieving a level of renown rare among scientists.

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors find it difficult to ignore patients’ complaints about statins, which are much cheaper, even though clinical trials have found that they have minimal side effects.

headline.main: New Alternatives to Statins Add to a Quandary on Cholesterol
headline.print_headline: New Drugs Add to a Quandary on Cholesterol

docs.abstract: Two newly-approved cholesterol-lowering drugs, Praluent and Repatha, may offer solution for patients who fear side effects of commonly prescribed statins; cost of drugs, over $14,000 per year, adds to quandary for doctors, who must consider full impact on patients' lives of lifelong medicines they prescribe (Series: Mending Hearts).
docs.snippet: Doctors find it difficult to ignore patients’ complaints about statins, which are much cheaper, even though clinical trials have found that they have minimal side effects.

docs.lead_paragraph: To some, the news that most studies do not hold up when retested came as a relief, like the field had “come clean,” one expert said.

headline.main: Psychologists Welcome Analysis Casting Doubt on Their Work
headline.print_headline: Analysis Casting Doubt on Their Work Is Still Welcomed by Many Psychologists

docs.abstract: Report in journal Science citing ability to reproduce only 36 percent of findings from almost 100 studies published in top three psychology journals polarizes community; report causes outrage among some and relief among others who are making efforts to increase transparency and improve data accuracy.
docs.snippet: To some, the news that most studies do not hold up when retested came as a relief, like the field had “come clean,” one expert said.
